Introduction

Postpartum endometritis, an infection of the endometrial lining after delivery, poses a significant concern in postnatal care.  It is triggered by a polymicrobial infection from the introduction of mixed anaerobic and aerobic bacteria into the uterus during childbirth.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Several factors contribute to the development of postpartum endometritis.  Most risk factors create opportunities for bacterial infiltration into the uterus, leading to infection and subsequent inflammation; these include:



  • Cesarean delivery (highest risk)
  • Prolonged labor
  • Prolonged, prelabor rupture of membranes
  • Multiple cervical examinations during labor
  • Operative vaginal delivery
  • Group B Streptococcus colonization

Clinical presentation



  • Fever (>38 C [100.4 F]) >24 hours postpartum (fever <24 hr postpartum is considered physiologic)
  • Uterine tenderness
  • Malodorous lochia
  • Midline lower abdominal pain
  • Soft, noncontracted uterus (leading to postpartum hemorrhage)


In severe cases, complications such as sepsis or pelvic abscess formation may occur.

Diagnostic evaluation



Postpartum endometritis is diagnosed clinically based on â‰¥2 of the following:



  • Fever (â‰¥38 C [100.4 F]) >24 hours postpartum
  • Uterine/lower abdominal tenderness (with no other obvious cause)
  • Malodorous lochia


Laboratory tests are often performed but are nondiagnostic.  They include a complete blood count with differential, which can show infection rather than physiologic leukocytosis based on increased bands.  Urine culture is also routinely performed to rule out urinary tract infection.  Blood and endometrial cultures are not typically collected because postpartum endometritis results from a polymicrobial infection and cultures do not change management.



Transvaginal ultrasonography is not typically performed because the findings are nonspecific and may be normal postpartum changes.  However, if there is concern for abscess formation (eg, not improving on antibiotics), ultrasonography or CT scan may be performed.

Differential diagnosis



  • Normal postpartum course:  fever is common <24 hours postpartum due to changes in hormone levels after delivery; however, it is considered pathologic at >24 hours and required further investigation to an underlying etiology.
  • Urinary tract infection:  is common postpartum due to prolonged catheterization during labor and delivery.  However, patients do not have malodorous lochia or uterine tenderness.
  • Perineal laceration or surgical incision infection:  after cesarean delivery or a repaired perineal location, infection at the surgical site can cause fever, but there is typically localized pain, erythema, and drainage.
  • Retained products of conception and pelvic abscess:  retained placental tissue can cause fever, uterine tenderness, and abnormal bleeding.  Patients who do respond to antibiotics should undergo ultrasonography to evaluate for these conditions.

Management



Prompt initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy is fundamental in managing postpartum endometritis.  Antibiotic coverage should cover both anaerobic and aerobic bacteria; in addition, group B Streptococcus (GBS) colonization status helps determine the medication regimen.



In patients without GBS colonization, antibiotic therapy is with:



  • Clindamycin plus gentamicin


In patients with either unknown or positive GBS colonization, antibiotic therapy is with:



  • Ampicillin plus clindamycin plus gentamicin (the addition of ampicillin is due to the increasing antibiotic resistance of GBS to clindamycin)
  • OR Ampicillin-sulbactam


Antibiotics are continued until the patient has been afebrile for 24-48 hours and no longer has symptoms (eg, no uterine tenderness).  Supportive measures include rest, hydration, and pain management.  Surgical intervention may be necessary in severe cases, particularly for abscess drainage.

Complications and prognosis



Most patients with postpartum endometritis recover within 24-48 hours after the initiation of antibiotics.  A small percentage of patients can develop a pelvic abscess, which requires incision and drainage.



A rare, but serious complication of postpartum endometritis is septic pelvic thrombophlebitis (infected clot in the ovarian vessels), which classically presents with cyclic fevers unresponsive to antibiotics and continued pelvic pain.  Treatment of this condition includes antibiotics and anticoagulation.

Prevention



Preventing postpartum endometritis involves various strategies.  Prescribing antibiotic prophylaxis before cesarean delivery, maintaining aseptic techniques during labor and delivery, and minimizing unnecessary cervical examination can significantly reduce the risk for infection.
